Guidelines for configuration and dependency management

Core rules
- Only declare configuration that differs from the tool/plugin default. If it works without explicit config, leave it out.
- Do not repeat default values (including default times, thresholds, or flags).
- Use pnpm for adding or updating dependencies.

Style and maintainability
- Keep configs minimal and focused: one change per entry.
- Prefer clarity and readability: short keys, sensible ordering, and comments when the rationale is non-obvious.
- Avoid duplication across configs; centralize shared settings when appropriate.

Why this matters
- Less code to maintain and review
- Fewer regressions when defaults evolve
- Cleaner, more readable repositories


Notes
- When writing plugin code, assume default behavior unless a test or requirement shows otherwise.
- Document any non-default choices briefly so future maintainers know why they exist.
